'''Floyd's triangle''' is a [[right angle|right-angled]] [[triangle|triangular]] array of [[natural number]]s, used in computer science education. It is named after [[Robert Floyd]]. It is defined by filling the rows of the triangle with consecutive numbers, starting with a 1 in the top left corner: {| style="margin:0.5em auto; width:auto" |- bgcolor=#F8F8F8 align=center | 1 |- bgcolor=#F8F8F8 align=center | 2 | 3 |- bgcolor=#F8F8F8 align=center | 4 | 5 | 6 |- bgcolor=#F8F8F8 align=center | 7 | 8 | 9 | 10 |- bgcolor=#F8F8F8 align=center | 11 | 12 | 13 | 14 | 15 |} Beginning programmers are often assigned the task of writing a program to print out the table in the format shown.{{citation|title=A first course in computer programming using PASCAL|first=Arthur M.|last=Keller|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=1982|page=39}}.{{citation|title=Pascal with program design|first=James F.|last=Peters|publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston|year=1986|pages=137, 154}}. The numbers along the left edge of the triangle are the [[lazy caterer's sequence]] and the numbers along the right edge are the [[triangular number]]s. The ''n''th row sums to ''n''(''n''2 + 1)/2, the constant of an ''n'' × ''n'' [[magic square]] {{OEIS|id=A006003}}. Summing up the row sums in Floyd's triangle reveals the '''doubly triangular numbers''' (triangular numbers with an index that is triangular){{OEIS|id=A002817}}{{citation|title=Doubly Triangular Numbers OEIS A002817|first=Tony|last=Foster||year=2015|}}. 1            = '''1''' = '''T'''('''T'''(1))


1            = '''6''' = '''T'''('''T'''(2))
2 + 3


1
2 + 3     = '''21''' = '''T'''('''T'''(3))
4 + 5 + 6
==See also == *[[Pascal's triangle]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Floyd's_triangle Floyd's triangle at Rosetta code] [[Category:Triangles of numbers]] [[Category:Computer programming]] [[Category:Computer science education]]

A '''fundamental ephemeris''' of the [[Solar System]] is a [[Computer simulation|model]] of the objects of the system in space, with all of their positions and motions accurately represented. It is intended to be a high-precision primary reference for prediction and observation of those positions and motions, and which provides a basis for further refinement of the model. It is generally not intended to cover the entire life of the Solar System; usually a short-duration time span, perhaps a few centuries, is represented to high accuracy. Some long ephemerides cover several millennia to medium accuracy.
They are published by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory as [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory Development Ephemeris|Development Ephemeris]]. The latest releases include DE430 which covers planetary and lunar ephemeris from Dec 21, 1549 to Jan 25, 2650 with high precision and is intended for general use for modern time periods . DE431 was created to cover a longer time period Aug 15, -13200 to March 15, 17191 with slightly less precision for use with historic observations and far reaching forecasted positions. DE432 was released as a minor update to DE430 with improvements to the Pluto barycenter in support of the [[New Horizons]] mission.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://naif.jpl.nasa.gov/pub/naif/generic_kernels/spk/planets/de432.pdf|title=JPL Memo IOM 392R-14-003|last=Folkner|first=|date=April 30, 2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Description== The set of physical laws and numerical constants used in the calculation of the ephemeris must be self-consistent and precisely specified. The ephemeris must be calculated strictly in accordance with this set, which represents the most current knowledge of all relevant physical forces and effects. Current fundamental ephemerides are typically released with exact descriptions of all mathematical models, methods of computation, observational data, and adjustment to the observations at the time of their announcement.<ref>See, for instance, {{cite web|url=http://iau-comm4.jpl.nasa.gov/de405iom/de405iom.pdf |title=JPL Planetary and Lunar Ephemerides DE405/LE405 |author=Standish |date=1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220062549/http://iau-comm4.jpl.nasa.gov/de405iom/de405iom.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-20 |df= }}; {{cite web|url=http://www.imcce.fr/inpop/inpop10a.pdf |title=INPOP10a |author=Fienga |display-authors=etal |date=2010 }}; {{cite web|url=http://iau-comm4.jpl.nasa.gov/EPM2004.pdf |title=High-Precision Ephemerides of Planets—EPM and Determination of Some Astronomical Constants |author=Pitjeva |date=2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081031065523/http://iau-comm4.jpl.nasa.gov/EPM2004.pdf |archivedate=2008-10-31 |df= }}</ref> This may not have been the case in the past, as fundamental ephemerides were then computed from a collection of methods derived over a span of decades by many researchers.<ref name="sandw">{{cite web |url=ftp://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/pub/eph/planets/ioms/ExplSupplChap8.pdf |author=Standish and Williams |title=CHAPTER 8: Orbital Ephemerides of the Sun, Moon, and Planets |date=2010}} A chapter from an as-yet-unpublished (Feb 2012) version of the ''Explanatory Supplement'' (see [[#Sources|Sources]])</ref>
The independent variable of the ephemeris is always time. In the case of the most current ephemerides, it is a [[Coordinate time|relativistic coordinate time]] scale equivalent to the [[International Astronomical Union|IAU]] definition of [[Barycentric Coordinate Time|TCB]].<ref name="sandw" /> In the past, [[Solar time|mean solar time]] (before the discovery of the non-uniform [[rotation of the Earth]]) and [[ephemeris time]] (before the implementation of [[Post-Newtonian expansion|relativistic gravitational equations]]) were used. The remainder of the ephemeris can consist of either the mathematical equations and initial conditions which describe the motions of the bodies of the Solar System, of tabulated data calculated from those equations and conditions, or of condensed mathematical representations of the tabulated data.
A fundamental ephemeris is the basis from which apparent ephemerides, phenomena, and orbital elements are computed for astronomical, nautical, and surveyors' almanacs. Apparent ephemerides give positions and motions of Solar System bodies as seen by observers from the surface of Earth, and are useful for astronomers, navigators, and surveyors in planning observations and in reducing the data acquired, although much of the work of latter two has been supplanted by [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] technology. Phenomena are events related to the configurations of Solar System bodies, for instance [[Sunrise|rise]] and [[Sunset|set]] times, [[Lunar phase|phases]], [[eclipse]]s and [[occultation]]s, and have many civil and scientific applications. [[Orbital elements]] are descriptions of the motion of a body at a particular instant, used for further short-time-span calculation of the body's position when high accuracy is not required.
==History== Astronomers have been tasked with computing accurate ephemerides, originally for purposes of sea navigation, from at least the 18th century. In England, [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] founded the [[Royal Observatory, Greenwich|Royal Observatory]] in 1675,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rmg.co.uk/royal-observatory/history/ |title=History of the Royal Observatory, Greenwich}}</ref> which began publishing ''[[The Nautical Almanac]]'' in 1766.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aa.usno.navy.mil/publications/docs/na_history.php |title=History of The Nautical Almanac}}</ref> In France, the ''[[Bureau des Longitudes]]'' was founded in 1795 to publish the ''[[Connaissance des Temps]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imcce.fr/en/presentation/histoire_imcce.php |title=History of the IMCCE}}</ref> The early fundamental ephemerides of these publications came from many different sources and authors as the science of [[celestial mechanics]] matured.<ref>See ''Explanatory Supplement'' (1961), chap. 7 or ''Explanatory Supplement'' (1992), chap. 13 for extensive lists of sources of the early fundamental ephemerides of the ''Nautical Almanac''. (see [[#Sources|Sources]])</ref>
At the end of the 19th century, the analytical methods of [[Perturbation (astronomy)|general perturbations]] reached the probable limits of what could be accomplished by hand calculation. The planetary "theories" of [[Simon Newcomb|Newcomb]]<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zKoUAQAAMAAJ |last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Motion of the Earth on its Axis and Around the Sun |journal=Astronomical Papers Prepared for the Use of the American Ephemeris and Nautical Almanac |volume=VI |issue=Part I |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, DC}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zKoUAQAAMAAJ |last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Heliocentric Motion of Mercury |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VI, part II|pages=171 |bibcode=1898USNAO...6..171N }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zKoUAQAAMAAJ |last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Heliocentric Motion of Venus |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VI, part III|pages=271 |bibcode=1898USNAO...6..271N }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zKoUAQAAMAAJ |last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Heliocentric Motion of Mars |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VI, part IV|pages=383 |bibcode=1898USNAO...6..383N }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tHfmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP5 |last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Heliocentric Motion of Uranus |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VII|bibcode=1898USNAO...7R...1N }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tHfmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP5|last=Newcomb |date=1898 |title=Tables of the Heliocentric Motion of Neptune |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VII|bibcode=1898USNAO...7Q...1N }}</ref> and [[George William Hill|Hill]]<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tHfmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP5|last=Hill |date=1898 |title=Tables of Jupiter |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VII}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tHfmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP5|last=Hill |date=1898 |title=Tables of Saturn |journal=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=VII}}</ref> formed the fundamental ephemerides of the ''Nautical Almanac'' at that time. For the Sun, Mercury, Venus, and Mars, the tabulations of the ''[[Astronomical Almanac]]'' continued to be derived from the work of Newcomb and Ross<ref>{{citation |last=Ross |date=1917 |title=New Elements of Mars |series=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=IX |issue=Part II}}</ref> through 1983. In France, the works of [[Leverrier|LeVerrier]]<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0004&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Théorie et Tables du Mouvement Apparent du Soleil |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire Impérial de Paris |volume=IV |language=French |author=LeVerrier |date=1858}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0005&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Théorie et Tables du Mouvement de Mercure |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire Impérial de Paris |volume=V |language=French |author=LeVerrier |date=1859}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0006&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Théorie et Tables du Mouvement de Vénus |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire Impérial de Paris, Mémoires |volume=VI |language=French |author=LeVerrier |date=1861}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0006&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Théorie et Tables du Mouvement de Mars |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire Impérial de Paris, Mémoires |volume=VI |language=French |author=LeVerrier |date=1861}}</ref><ref>LeVerrier developed and published his original theories of the outer planets in ''Annales de l'Observatoire de Paris, Mémoires |volume=X-|volume=XIV ''</ref> and [[Jean Baptiste Aimable Gaillot|Gaillot]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0031&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Tables Rectifiées du Mouvement de Jupiter |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire de Paris, Mémoires |volume=XXXI |language=French |author=Gaillot |date=1913}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0024&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Tables Rectifiées du Mouvement de Saturne |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire de Paris, Mémoires |volume=XXIV |language=French |author=Gaillot |date=1904}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/iarticle_query?journal=AnPar&volume=0028&type=SCREEN_THMB |title=Tables Nouvelles des Mouvements d'Uranus et de Neptune |journal=Annales de l'Observatoire de Paris, Mémoires |volume=XXVIII|language=French |author=Gaillot |date=1910}}</ref> formed the fundamental ephemeris of the ''Connaissance des Temps''.
From the mid 20th century, work began on [[numerical integration]] of the [[equations of motion]] on [[IBM SSEC|early computing machines]] for purposes of producing fundamental ephemerides for the ''Astronomical Almanac''. Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and Pluto were based on the work of Eckert, ''et al''.<ref>{{citation |author=Eckert |author2=Brouwer |author3=Clemence |date=1951 |title=Coordinates of the Five Outer Planets 1953–2060 |series=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=XII}}</ref> and Clemence<ref>{{citation |author=Clemence |date=1954 |title=Perturbations of the Five Outer Planets by the Four Inner Ones |series=Astronom. Papers American Ephem. |volume=XIII |issue=Part V}}</ref> through 1983. The fundamental ephemeris of the Moon, always a difficult problem in celestial mechanics, remained a work-in-progress through the early 1980s. It was based originally on the work of Brown,<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=nBFLAAAAYAAJ |author=Brown |date=1919 |title=Tables of the Motion of the Moon |publisher=Yale University Press, New Haven, CT}}</ref> with updates and corrections by Clemence, ''et al''.<ref>{{cite journal |date=1952 |title=Aberration in the Lunar Ephemeris |journal=Astronomical Journal |volume=57 |pages=46–47|bibcode=1952AJ.....57...46C |doi=10.1086/106703 |last1=Clemence |first1=G. M |last2=Porter |first2=J. G |last3=Sadler |first3=D. H }}</ref> and Eckert, ''et al''.<ref>{{cite journal |bibcode=1966AJ.....71..314E |date=1966 |title=Transformation of the Lunar Coordinates and Orbital Parameters |journal=Astronomical Journal |volume=71 |pages=314–332|doi=10.1086/109923 |last1=Eckert |first1=W. J |last2=Walker |first2=M. J |last3=Eckert |first3=D }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |date=1969 |title=A Note on the Evaluation of the Latitude of the Moon |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=146 |issue=4 |pages=473–478|bibcode=1969MNRAS.146..473E |doi=10.1093/mnras/146.4.473 |last1=Eckert |first1=W. J |last2=Van Flandern |first2=T. C |last3=Wilkins |first3=G. A }}</ref><ref>See also {{citation |author=Nautical Almanac Office, U.S. Naval Observatory |author2=H.M. Nautical Almanac Office, Royal Greenwich Observatory |date=1954 |title=Improved Lunar Ephemeris |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, DC}}.</ref>
Starting in 1984, a revolution in the methods of producing fundamental ephemerides began.<ref>See {{cite journal |date=1983 |bibcode=1983A&A...125..150N |title=DE 102 – A numerically integrated ephemeris of the moon and planets spanning forty-four centuries |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=125 |issue=1|pages=150 |author1=Newhall |first1=X. X |last2=Standish |first2=E. M |last3=Williams |first3=J. G }} for a good description of the new methods from their early days.</ref> From 1984 through 2002, the fundamental ephemeris of the ''Astronomical Almanac'' was the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]'s [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory Development Ephemeris|DE200/LE200]], a fully numerically-integrated ephemeris fitted to modern position and velocity observations of the Sun, Moon, and planets. From 2003 onward (as of Feb 2012), [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory Development Ephemeris|JPL's DE405/LE405]], an integrated ephemeris referred to the [[International Celestial Reference Frame]], has been used.<ref name="sandw" /> In France, the ''Bureau des Longitudes'' began using their machine-generated semi-analytical theory VSOP82 in 1984,<ref>{{cite journal |bibcode=1982A&A...114..278B |title=Théorie du mouvement de l'ensemble des planètes. Solution VSOP82 |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=114 |pages=278 |date=1982 |language=French|author1=Bretagnon |first1=P }}</ref> and their work continued with the founding of the ''[[IMCCE|Institut de mécanique céleste et de calcul des éphémérides]]'' in 1998 and the INPOP<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imcce.fr/inpop/inpop06_preprint.pdf |title=INPOP06. A new numerical planetary ephemeris |author=Fienga |display-authors=etal |date=2006}}; {{cite web |url=http://www.imcce.fr/inpop/inpop08_preprint.pdf |title=INPOP08, a 4-D planetary ephemeris |author=Fienga |display-authors=etal |date=2008}}; {{cite web |url=http://www.imcce.fr/inpop/inpop10a.pdf |title=INPOP10a |author=Fienga |display-authors=etal |date=2010}}</ref> series of numerical ephemerides. DE405/LE405 were superseded by DE421/LE421 in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=ftp://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/pub/eph/planets/README.txt|title=JPL Planetary and Lunar Ephemerides|last=Folkner|first=William|date=April 30, 2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

{{nihongo|'''Hara hachi bun me'''|腹八分目/はらはちぶんめ}},<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jisho.org/search/%E8%85%B9%E5%85%AB%E5%88%86%E7%9B%AE |title=Jisho.org online Japanese-English dictionary |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2015 |website=jisho.org |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-02 |quote=}}</ref> (or '''hara hachi bu''', and sometimes misspelled '''hari hachi bu'''), is a [[Confucianism|Confucian]]<ref>Buettner, pp. 7, 227</ref> teaching that instructs people to eat until they are 80 percent full.<ref name=Okinawa /> Roughly, in English the [[Japan]]ese phrase translates to, “Eat until you are eight parts (out of ten) full”<ref name="Okinawa">{{cite book| author = Willcox BJ |author2=Willcox DC |author3=Suzuki M| title = The Okinawa Program : How the World's Longest-Lived People Achieve Everlasting Health And How You Can Too| year = 2002| publisher = [[Three Rivers Press]]| isbn = 978-0-609-80750-7| pages = [https://books.google.ca/books?id=2r82Zk5qjxIC&pg=PA86#v=onepage&q&f=false 86–87] }}</ref> or “belly 80 percent full”.<ref name="Grossman">{{cite journal|author=Grossman, Terry|title=Latest advances in antiaging medicine|year=2005|url=http://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/kjm/54/2/85/_pdf|format=PDF|journal=The Keio Journal of Medicine|volume=54|issue=2|pages=85–94|doi=10.2302/kjm.54.85}}</ref>
==Okinawans== [[File:Body mass index chart.svg|thumb|400px|alt=Chart showing underweight, normal weight, overweight and obese|[[Body mass index]] chart]] As of the early 21st century, [[Okinawa]]ns in [[Japan]], through practicing ''hara hachi bu'', are the only human population to have a self-imposed habit of calorie restriction.<ref name=Okinawa /> They consume about 1,800<ref name=Grossman /> to 1,900 kilo-calories per day.<ref>Beuttner, p. 233</ref> Their elders' typical [[body mass index]] (BMI) is about 18 to 22, compared to a typical BMI of 26 or 27 for adults over 60 in the [[United States]].<ref name="BasicNutrition">{{cite book| author = Smolin LA|author2=Grosvenor MB| title = Basic Nutrition| year = 2004| publisher = [[Infobase Publishing]]| isbn = 0-7910-7850-7 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=pqueMlren1cC&pg=PA134 | pages = 134 }}</ref> Okinawa has the world's highest proportion of [[centenarian]]s, at approximately 50 per 100,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Okinawa's Centenarians|url=http://www.okicent.org/cent.html|work=The Okinawa Centenarian Study|accessdate=21 April 2013}}</ref>
Biochemist [[Clive McCay]], a professor at [[Cornell University]] in the 1930s, reported that significant [[calorie restriction]] prolonged life in laboratory animals.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ingram, DK|title=Development of calorie restriction mimetics as a prolongevity strategy|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|year=2004|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|doi=10.1196/annals.1297.074 |display-authors=etal|volume=1019|pages=412–423|pmid=15247056}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/EAD/pdf_guides/RMA01087.pdf|format=PDF|title=Clive McCay papers, 1920-1967 | publisher = [[Cornell University Library]] | accessdate=June 1, 2011}}</ref> Authors Bradley and Craig Wilcox and Makoto Suzuki believe that ''hara hachi bu'' may act as a form of calorie restriction, thus extending practitioners' [[life expectancy]]. They believe ''hara hachi bun me'' assists in keeping the average Okinawan's BMI low, and this is thought to be due to the delay in the stomach stretch receptors that help signal [[Hunger (motivational state)|satiety]]. The result of not practising ''hara hachi bun me'' is a constant stretching of the stomach which in turn increases the amount of food needed to feel full.<ref name=Okinawa />
==Influence== In the 1965 book ''[[Philip Kapleau#Writings|Three Pillars of Zen]]'', the author quotes [[Hakuun Yasutani]] in his lecture for [[zazen]] beginners as telling his students about the book ''Zazen Yojinki'' (''Precautions to Observe in Zazen''), written circa 1300, which advises practitioners to eat about two-thirds of their capacity. Yasutani advises his students to eat only eighty percent of their capacity, and he repeats a Japanese proverb: “eight parts of a full stomach sustain the man; the other two sustain the doctor”.<ref>{{cite book| last1 = Kapleau| first1 = Philip| title = The Three pillars of Zen: teaching, practice, and enlightenment| year = 1989| publisher = Anchor Books| location = New York| isbn = 0-385-26093-8| pages = 43–44| ref = harv }}</ref>
''Hara hachi bun me'' was popularized in the United States by a variety of modern books on diet and longevity.<ref>Buettner, pp. 83, 96, 103, 233</ref><ref>{{cite book| last = Beckerman| first = James| title = The Flex Diet| year = 2011| publisher = [[Simon & Schuster|Touchstone]]| isbn = 978-1-4391-5569-1| pages = 162–163 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Okinawa diet]] * [[Calorie restriction]]

{{Nanotechnology}}
The '''[[IEEE Standards Association|IEEE]] P1906.1''' - Recommended Practice for Nanoscale and Molecular Communication Framework<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-01-01|title=IEEE Recommended Practice for Nanoscale and Molecular Communication Framework|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/lpdocs/epic03/wrapper.htm?arnumber=7378262|journal=IEEE Std 1906.1-2015|pages=1–64|doi=10.1109/IEEESTD.2016.7378262}}</ref> is a standards working group sponsored by the [[IEEE Communications Society]] Standards Development Board whose goal is to develop a common framework for [[nanoscale networking|nanoscale]] and [[molecular communication]].<ref>[http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1906.1.html IEEE P1906.1 - Recommended Practice for Nanoscale and Molecular Communication Framework]</ref> Because this is an [[emerging technology]], the standard is designed to encourage innovation by reaching consensus on a common definition, terminology, framework, goals, metrics, and use-cases that encourage innovation and enable the technology to advance at a faster rate. The draft passed an initial sponsor balloting with comments on January 2, 2015. The comments were addressed by the working group and the resulting draft ballot passed again on August 17, 2015. Finally, additional material regarding [[SBML]] was contributed and the final draft passed again on October 15, 2015. The draft standard was approved by IEEE RevCom in the final quarter of 2015.
== Membership ==
[[Working group]] membership includes experts in industry and academia with strong backgrounds in [[mathematical modeling]], [[engineering]], [[physics]], [[economics]] and [[biological sciences]].<ref>[https://mentor.ieee.org/1906.1/bp/StartPage IEEE COM/Nanoscale and Molecular Communications Working Group]</ref>
== Content ==
Electronic components such as [[transistors]], or [[electrical]]/[[Radio propagation|electromagnetic]] message carriers whose operation is similar at the [[Macroscopic scale|macroscale]] and [[nanoscale]] are excluded from the definition. A human-engineered, [[Artificiality|synthetic]] component must form part of the system because it is important to avoid standardizing nature or physical processes. The definition of [[communication]], particularly in the area of [[cell-surface]] interactions as viewed by [[biologist]]s versus non-biologists has been a topic of debate. The interface is viewed as a [[communication channel]], whereas the '[[Cell signaling|receptor-signaling]]-[[gene expression]]' events are the network.
The draft currently comprises: definition, terminology, framework, metrics, use-cases, and reference code ([[Ns (simulator)|ns-3]]).<ref>Bush, S.; Paluh, J.; Piro, G.; Rao, V.; Prasad, V.; Eckford, A., [https://dx.doi.org/10.1109/TMBMC.2015.2465513 "Defining Communication at the Bottom,"] in Molecular, Biological and Multi-Scale Communications, IEEE Transactions on, vol.PP, no.99, pp.1-1.</ref>
The standard provides a very broad foundation and encompasses all approaches to nanoscale communication. While there have been many superficial academic attempts to classify nanoscale communication approaches, the standard considers two fundamental approaches: [[Wave–particle duality|waves and particles]]. This includes any hybrid of the two as well as [[quasiparticle]]s.
A unique contribution of the standard is an [[ns-3]] reference model that enables users to build upon the standard components.
=== Definition === * A precise definition of [[nanoscale networking]] ** [[Academic]] and [[Industry|industrial]] researchers have been playing with the concept of nanoscale communication networks, but without a common, well-defined, and precise definition. The IEEE P1906.1 working group has adopted the definitive specification for a nanoscale communication network. The draft standard sets the context of communication within [[length scale]]s by defining communication length scales ranging from the [[Planck length]] scale to [[Theory of relativity|relativistic]] length scales. A focus is upon the progression of physical changes that impact communication as [[length scale]] is reduced.
=== Terminology === * Common terminology for nanoscale networking ** Nanoscale communication networking is a highly [[interdisciplinary]] endeavor. A clear, common language is required so that interdisciplinary researchers can work smoothly together and minimize cross-discipline misunderstanding due to the common definitions that are defined differently in different fields. The P1906.1 working group has reached consensus on common definitions unique to nanoscale communication networks.
=== Framework === * A framework for ad hoc nanoscale networking ** There is a pressing need for a [[conceptual model]] of nanoscale networks. A standardized platform for nanoscale communication [[network simulation]] is needed. Researchers are developing simulation models and packages for components related to nanoscale communication networks; however the simulation components are not interoperable, even at a conceptual level. The IEEE P1906.1 working group has adopted a nanoscale communication framework that addresses this need. The result of the framework is known as the ''standard model.''
=== Metrics === * Metrics and analytical model are in development ** The working group is currently in the process of developing [[Metric (mathematics)|metric]]s to uniquely characterize nanoscale communication networks.<ref>Bush, S.F.; Goel, S., [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6708562&isnumber=6704980 "Persistence Length as a Metric for Modeling and Simulation of Nanoscale Communication Networks,"] Selected Areas in Communications, IEEE Journal on, vol.31, no.12, pp.815-824, December 2013 doi: 10.1109/JSAC.2013.SUP2.12130014.</ref> Twenty metrics have been defined: *** Message Deliverability *** Message Lifetime *** Information Density *** [[Bandwidth delay product|Bandwidth-Delay Product]] *** Information and Communication Energy *** [[Coefficient of restitution|Collision Behavior]] *** Mass Displacement *** Positioning Accuracy of Message Carriers *** [[Persistence length|Persistence Length]] *** [[Diffusion#Diffusion flux|Diffusive Flux]] *** [[Langevin equation|Langevin Noise]] *** [[Sensitivity and specificity|Specificity]] *** [[Relative binding affinity|Affinity]] *** [[Sensitivity and specificity|Sensitivity]] *** [[Angle of arrival|Angular (Angle-of-Arrival) Spectrum]] *** [[Time of arrival|Delay (Time-of-Arrival) Spectrum]] *** [[Active networking|Active Network Programmability]] *** Perturbation Rate *** Supersystem Degradation *** Bandwidth-Volume Ratio
=== Use-Cases === * Specific example applications of the standard ** Specific [[Use case|use-case]]s of nanoscale communication implemented using the P1906.1 definition and framework are provided. A standard mapping between a use-case, or implementation, and the standard model of the framework allows a brief summary of the information required about a use-case to understand its relevance to a nanoscale communication network.
=== Reference model === * Reference code to model the recommended practice is in development ** [[Ns-3]] reference code is currently in development that implements the developing IEEE P1906.1 recommended practice. The communication framework conceived by the P1906.1 working group has been implemented. A simple example highlighting the interaction and the role of each component in [[electromagnetic]]-based,<ref>[https://github.com/ieee-p1906-1-reference-code/p1906-dev/tree/master/p1906/model-em 1906 NS-3 Electromagnetic Model]</ref> [[diffusion]]-based,<ref>[https://github.com/ieee-p1906-1-reference-code/p1906-dev/tree/master/p1906/model-mol 1906 NS-3 Diffusion Model]</ref> and [[molecular motor]]-based communication<ref>[https://github.com/ieee-p1906-1-reference-code/p1906-dev/tree/motor-model 1906 NS-3 Molecular Motor Model]</ref> at the [[nanoscale]] has been developed.
== Applications == Applications are numerous, however, there appears to be strong emphasis on medical and biological use-cases in [[nanomedicine]].
== Simulation software == The IEEE P1906.1 working group is developing [[ns-3]] nanoscale simulation software that implements the IEEE 1906.1 standard and serves as a reference model and base for development of a wide-variety of interoperable small-scale communication physical layer models.<ref>[https://github.com/ieee-p1906-1-reference-code 1906 NS-3 Electromagnetic Model]</ref>
== Literature review == The Best Readings on nanoscale communication networks provides good background information related to the standard.<ref>[http://www.comsoc.org/blog/discover-best-readings-nanoscale-communication-networks DISCOVER THE BEST READINGS IN NANOSCALE COMMUNICATION NETWORKS]</ref> The Topics section breaks down the information using the standard approach.<ref>[http://www.comsoc.org/best-readings/topics/nanoscale-communication-networks#topics BEST READINGS TOPICS ON NANOSCALE COMMUNICATION NETWORKS]</ref>
== Building on IEEE 1906.1 == IEEE 1906.1 is the foundation for nanoscale communication. Additional standards are expected to build upon it.
'''IEEE 1906.1.1 Standard Data Model for Nanoscale Communication Systems ''' The Standard Data Model for Nanoscale Communication Systems defines a [[network management]] and configuration [[data model]] for nanoscale communication.<ref>[https://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1906.1.1.html IEEE 1906.1.1 - Standard Data Model for Nanoscale Communication Systems]</ref> This data model has several goals: * Ensure compliance with IEEE 1906.1-2015 * Describe the essence of nanoscale communication * Capture fundamental physics of IEEE 1906.1-2015 * Define configuration and management of simulation and experimental systems * Provide a self-describing data structure for experimental data.
The data model is written in [[YANG]] and will enable remote remote configuration and operation of nanoscale communication over the Internet using [[NETCONF]].
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== References == * [http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1906.1.html IEEE P1906.1 - Recommended Practice for Nanoscale and Molecular Communication Framework Project Application Request (PAR)].
==External links== * [http://standards.ieee.org/develop/project/1906.1.html IEEE P1906.1 - Recommended Practice for Nanoscale and Molecular Communication Framework]
{{IEEE standards}}

'''ISC3 (Industrial Source Complex)''' model is a popular steady-state [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Gaussian plume model]] which can be used to assess pollutant concentrations from a wide variety of sources associated with an industrial complex. This model can account for the following: * [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Point, area, line, and volume sources]] * [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Settling and dry deposition of particles]] * [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Downwash]] * Separation of point sources * Limited terrain adjustment ISC3 operates in both [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|long-term and short-term]] modes. The screening version of ISC3 is [[List of atmospheric dispersion models#Screening models|SCREEN3]]. Very recently, the status of ISC3 as a [[List of atmospheric dispersion models#Preferred and recommended models|Preferred/Recommended Model]] of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|US Environmental Protection Agency]] has been withdrawn, but it can still be used as an alternative to the Preferred/Recommended models in regulatory applications with case-by-case justification to the reviewing authority. == Input data == ISC short term version required two sets of data: source data and hourly averaged [[meteorological]] data: === Source data === * Dimensions of the source * [[Air pollution|Emission]] discharge rate * Release height of the emission source === Meteorological data === * Ambient temperature, K * Wind direction * Wind speed, m/s * Atmospheric [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|stability classes]] (A through F, entered as 1 through 6) * [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Urban and rural]] mixing height, m == See also == *[[Bibliography of atmospheric dispersion modeling]] *[[Atmospheric dispersion modeling]] *[[List of atmospheric dispersion models]] ==Further reading== For those who are unfamiliar with air pollution dispersion modelling and would like to learn more about the subject, it is suggested that either one of the following books be read: *{{cite book | author=Turner, D.B. | title=Workbook of atmospheric dispersion estimates: an introduction to dispersion modeling| edition=2nd| publisher=CRC Press | year=1994 | isbn=1-56670-023-X }} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071105075907/http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= www.crcpress.com] *{{cite book | author=Beychok, M.R. | title=[[Fundamentals Of Stack Gas Dispersion]]| edition=4th| publisher=self-published | year=2005 | isbn=0-9644588-0-2}} [http://www.air-dispersion.com www.air-dispersion.com] ==External links== *[http://www.epa.gov/scram001/userg/regmod/isc3v1.pdf ISC3 User's Guide, Volume I] *[http://www.epa.gov/scram001/userg/regmod/isc3v2.pdf ISC3 User's Guide, Volume II] *[http://www.epa.gov/scram001/guidance/met/mmgrma.pdf Meteorological Monitoring Guidance for Regulatory Modeling Applications]
{{Atmospheric, Oceanographic and Climate Models}} [[Category:Atmospheric dispersion modeling]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox University | |name = Institute of Development Studies, Kolkata |image_name = Institute of Development Studies Kolkata Logo.png |image_size = 134px |caption = [[Logo]] of IDSK |motto = |type = [[Autonomous]], centre of excellence in social sciences |established = 2002 |affiliation = [[University of Calcutta]] |president = Sabyasachi Bhattacharya |location = Alipore Campus, University of Calcutta
|coor = {{Coord|22.5899|88.4104|region:IN_type:edu|display=inline, title}} |campus = urban |website = [http://idsk.edu.in/ Official website] }} The Institute of Development Studies Kolkata (IDSK<ref>{{Citation|title=Institute of Development Studies, Kolkata|date=2018-08-19|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Institute_of_Development_Studies,_Kolkata&oldid=855614501|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref>) is an [[Autonomy|autonomous]] [[research institute]] dedicated for [[Development Studies]] and related subfields in [[Kolkata]], [[India]]. It was established in 2002. [[Professor]] [[Amiya Kumar Bagchi]], who was appointed as its first-Director, is now Professor Emeritus of the Institute. It is affiliated with the [[University of Calcutta]]. It is devoted to advanced academic research and informed policy advice in the areas of literacy, education, health, women, employment, technology, communication human sciences and economic development.
== Affiliation and courses == This is an ICSSR research institute which conducts M. Phil. and Ph. D. courses in Development Studies<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://idsk.edu.in/|title=IDSK|website=IDSK|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> and short training programmes for research scholars<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://idsk.edu.in/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/PhD-Prospectus-2019.pdf|title=IDSK PhD Advt. 2019|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The specialisations in M. Phil. are Economics, History, Political Science, Sociology and Regional Development<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://idsk.edu.in/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/MPhil-Prospectus-2019.pdf|title=IDSK M. Phil. Programme|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== Location == The official location of the Institute is Department of Museology ,Laboratory Section, 5th floor, Alipore Campus, University of Calcutta.
== Library == The Institute's library started functioning in December 2002. It is now one of the leading libraries in India devoted to the economic and social sciences. It has rich collection of books, journals, research documents, reports, statistical databases of wide ranging areas in Anthropology, Economics, Ecology, Development Studies, Demography, Public Health, Political Science, History, Gender Studies, Human Sciences, Sociology, and Nutrition with special focus on North East India<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://idsk-opac.l2c2.co.in/pages.pl?p=idsk|title=Library of IDSK|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.<references group="http://idsk.edu.in/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/MPhil-Prospectus-2019.pdf" />
==External links== * [http://idsk.edu.in/ Official website] {{Calcutta University}}

The '''Institute of Ecotechnics''' is an educational, training and research [[Charitable organization|charity]] with a special interest in [[ecotechnology]], the environment, [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]], and heritage.<ref name="CharityCommission">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = Institute Of Ecotechnics | publisher = [[Charity Commission for England and Wales]] | date = 2017 | url = http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=1081259&subid=0 | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109134141/http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=1081259&subid=0 | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref> With its U.K. headquarters in [[London]], England and its U.S. in Santa Fe, NM, the institute was founded to "develop and practice the discipline of ecotechnics: the ecology of technics, and the technics of ecology."<ref name="IE About">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = About us | publisher = Institute of Ecotechnics | date = 2017 | url = http://ecotechnics.edu/about/ | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109134007/http://ecotechnics.edu/about/ | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref>
Ecotechnology is a newly-emerging [[applied science]] that deals with the relationship between humanity and the [[biosphere]].<ref name="IE About" /> It involves the use of [[Technology|technological]] means for [[ecosystem]] management. It seeks to fulfill human needs, based on a deep understanding of natural ecosystems, and minimizing disruption to those ecosystems.<ref name="CANR">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = What is Ecotechnology? | publisher = [[College of Agriculture and Natural Resources]] | date = 2017 | url = https://enst.umd.edu/research/research-centers/what-ecotechnology | accessdate = 9 November 2017 }}</ref>
The institute was founded and incorporated in [[New Mexico]] in 1973<ref name="The Environmentalist">{{cite journal | last1 = Allen | first1 = J.P. | last2 = Nelson | first2 = M. | last3 = Snyder | first3 = T.P. | title = Institute of Ecotechnics | journal = [[The Environmentalist]] | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 205–218 | publisher = The Environmentalist | date = Autumn 1984 | url = http://globalecotechnics.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Environmentalist-1985-IE-paper.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171110144033/http://www.globalecotechnics.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Environmentalist-1985-IE-paper.pdf | archive-date = 10 November 2017 | dead-url = no | doi = | id = | accessdate = 10 November 2017}}</ref> and incorporated in the UK in 1985.<ref name="CharityCommission" /> Its charity number in England and Wales is 1081259, and its company number is 1940123.<ref name="CharityCommission" /> It is also a [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit]] organization in the USA, number 74-3177755.<ref name="IE About" />
==Activities, Sailing ship == The Institute of Ecotechnics runs workshops, organizes conferences, and carries out ecological field research. It has developed agricultural, waste water and air purification, and biosphere technologies; and has published books on ecotechnics, ecological and cultural issues.<ref name="IE About" />
The ecological [[research vessel]], ''Heraclitus'', which the institute owns was designed and built with personnel from its first ecological project in New Mexico. The ship is a unique blend of ancient and modern: ferro-cement for its hull and deck, Chinese junk sails supplemented with diesel engine.The ''Heraclitus'' has sailed the oceans for decades since its launch in Oakland, California in 1975.<ref name="AnOther mag">{{cite web | author = Skidmore | first = Maisie | title = How You Can Support the Greatest Artwork on the Oceans | publisher = [[Another Magazine]] | date = 10 July 2017 | url = http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/9991/how-you-can-support-the-greatest-artwork-on-the-oceans | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109133634/http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/9991/how-you-can-support-the-greatest-artwork-on-the-oceans | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref> It has made twelve expeditions,.<ref name="AnOther mag" /> Some of them were a three year round the world voyage through the [[tropics|tropics exploring the origins of human culture. It also sailed]] up the [[Amazon River]] conducting ethnobotanical collections in Peru and circumnavigated South America with an expedition to [[Antarctica]].<ref name="Dreaming biosphere">{{cite book | last = Reider | first = Rebecca | authorlink = | title = Dreaming the Biosphere: The Theater of All Possibilities | publisher = [[University of New Mexico Press]] | date = 30 April 2010 | location = United States | pages = <!-- pages are unnumbered --> | isbn = 082634674X}}</ref><ref name="Global Ecotechnics Heraclitus">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = Expedition Vessel Heraclitus returns to Puerto Rico after 17 years | publisher = Global Ecotechnics | date = 3 February 2010 | url = http://www.globalecotechnics.com/2010/02/expedition-vessel-heraclitus-returns-to-puerto-rico-after-17-years/ | accessdate = 10 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171110124054/http://www.globalecotechnics.com/2010/02/expedition-vessel-heraclitus-returns-to-puerto-rico-after-17-years/ | archive-date = 10 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref> It collected corals off the Yucatan coast for the [[Biosphere 2]] project and from 1996-2008 teamed with the Biosphere Foundation to map and study coral reef health at many locations in the Pacific and Indian oceans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pcrf.org/science/sitelist.html|title=Planetary Coral Reef Foundation Coral Study Sites|last=|first=|date=|website=Biosphere Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alling.|first=Abigail|last2=et. al.|date=|title=Catastrophic coral mortality in the remote central Pacific Ocean: Kiribati, Phoenix islands 551, 1-19.|url=|journal=Atoll Research Bulletin|volume=(2007) 551|pages=1–19|via=}}</ref> Its most recent work was an oral history project among the port and sea people of the Mediterranean.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lifeartsmedia.com/heraclitus-contemporary-histories-of-mediterranean-ports|title=Heraclitus: Contemporary Histories of Mediterranean Ports|last=Snyder|first=Deborah|date=February 12, 2012|website=LAM (Life Arts Media)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=January 8, 2018}}</ref> The RV ''Heraclitus'' is in drydock in Roses, Spain undergoing a nearly complete rebuild after sailing some 270,000 miles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/9991/how-you-can-support-the-greatest-artwork-on-the-oceans|title=How you can support the greatest artwork on the oceans|last=Skidmore|first=Maisie|date=July 10, 2017|website=An Other Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=January 8, 2018}}</ref>
== Ecological field project consultancies == The Institute is involved in a series of ecological demonstration projects, selected in challenging biomes facing ecological degradation and cultural conflict. These were chosen because conventional approaches do not work, requiring innovative, "ecotechic" approaches with the goals of ecological upgrade, economic sustainability and to develop the capabilities of I.E. members and associates. The projects, and the Heraclitus, are places where hands-on educational programsand volunteer opportunities are provided.
Synergia Ranch, started in 1969, was the Institute's first ecological field project. There on 130 acres of desertifying high altitude sem-arid juniper/pinon grasslands, I.E. developed a program to restore the land, with the goal of creating an oasis in the desert. Over a thousand trees were planted, including 450 fruit trees, organic vegetable gardens and an extensive soil-building program using compost to restore lost fertility to an area which had been overgrazed and cleared for inappropriate broad-acre farming in the 1920s. Adobe buildings and a geodesic dome were built and artisan enterprises started including pottery, woodworking, iron working, clothing, leather.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Wastewater Gardener: Preserving the Planet One Flush at a Time|last=Nelson|first=Mark|publisher=Synergetic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0907791515|location=Santa Fe, NM|pages=Chapter 2, Flower Power at Synergia Ranch}}</ref> A construction firm build some three dozen adobe buildings in Santa Fe, contributing to a renaissance of traditional adobe architecture. The orchards and vegetable gardens are certified organic and in 2016 Synergia Ranch won the Good Earth award at the New Mexico Organic Agriculture conference in recognition of its land care.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://farmersmarketinstitute.org/news-and-events/synergia-ranch-good-earth-award/|title=Synergia Ranch Good Earth Award|last=Alexis|first=|date=February 23, 2017|website=Santa Fe Farmers Market Institute|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 January 2018}}</ref> The ecotechnic life style approach was to balance by engaging in three lines of work: ecology, enterprise and theater. The Theater of All Possibilities was based at Synergia Ranch for over a decade.
Les Marronniers near Aix-en-Provence, France, begun in 1976 is the ecotechnic field project in the Mediterranean biome. It has also served as a frequent location for the international conferences which I.E. organizes bringing together scientists, artists, engineers, managers and thinkers to engage on topics of broad interest. Les Marronniers has also revivified on 7 ha (17 acres) the mixed agriculture small holdings traditional in the area, with orchard, grapes, field crops, woodlot, domestic animals and art/sculpture workshops.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ecotechnics.edu/2011/02/les-marronniers-southern-france/|title=Les Marronniers Southern France|last=|first=|date=|website=Institute of Ecotechnics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref>
Birdwood Downs, a 4300 acre property in the Kimberley region of NW Western Australia, is the Institute's tropical savannah biomic project. Established in 1978, its goals are to regenerate an overgrazed ecology dominated by invasive scrub trees with drought-resistant grasses and legumes and to demostrate ecotechnic ways of living within a sometimes harsh climate.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Conceptual Model for Synergetic Management of the Savannahs, in Tothill, J.C. and Mott, J, eds. Ecology and Management of the World's Savannas|last=Nelson|first=Mark|publisher=Australian Academy of Science|year=1985|isbn=0851985351|location=Canberra, Australia:|pages=190 ff}}</ref> Robyn Tredwell, a director of I.E., managed the project from 1985 until her death in 2012 and was honored by being selected as the 1995 Australian Rural Woman of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/people/1477560?c=people|title=Robyn Tredwell, Australian Women's Register|last=|first=|date=|website=National Library of Australia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 December 2017}}</ref>
Recognizing that cities, part of the anthropogenic urban biome, are crucial players in the biosphere, I.E. helped establish the [[October Gallery]] in London in 1979 as its world city project. The October Gallery's goal is to find and showcase cutting-edge artists of the "transvangarde" from around the world. It also supports a robust educational program bringing many London school children into the gallery to meet artists and make art, as well as traveling exhibitions. Designed as a place where science and art can interact, it also hosts scientific, cultural and musical events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.octobergallery.co.uk/|title=October Gallery: Contemporary Art from Around the Planet|last=|first=|date=|website=October Gallery|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref>
In 1983, the Las Casas de la Selva project in Patillas, Puerto Rico became I.E. tropical rainforest project. On almost 1000 acres of mountainous secondary forest, the goal of the project is to show innovative methods of forest enrichment and to promote sustainable tropical forestry. With the cooperation of Puerto Rican departments of development and forestry, some 40,000 seedlings of valuable timber species were planted on one-third of the land. Line-planting was employed to minimize the impact on the surrounding forest and to conserve biodiversity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Mark|last2=et. al.|date=|title=The Impact of Hardwood Line-Planting on Tree and Amphibian Biodiversity in a Secondary Wet Tropical Forest, Southeast Puerto Rico|url=|journal=Journal of Sustainable Forestry|volume=(2010) 29(5)|pages=503–516|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Mark|last2=et. al.|date=|title=Enriched secondary subtropical forest through line-planting for sustainable timber production in Puerto Rico|url=|journal=Bois et Forêts des Tropiques|volume=(November 2011) 309(3)|pages=51–63|via=}}</ref> Las Casas won the 2016 Energy Globe national award for Puerto Rico and is recovering from severe damage caused by Hurricane Maria in 2017. During the island-wide cleanup from the Hurricane, Las Casas management are organizing the rescue of valuable hardwood trees felled which would otherwise be sent to landfills and wasted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gofundme.com/puerto-rico-hardwoods|title=Help us save that wood!|last=Rua|first=Andres|date=|website=GoFundMe|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 January 2018}}</ref>
== Biosphere 2 ==
Space Biosphere Ventures' [[Biosphere 2]] is another project in which the Institute of Ecotechnics was involved.<ref name="IFM">{{cite web|url=http://instituteformodern.co.uk/2017/proving-grounds-biosphere-2-then-and-now|title=Proving Grounds: Biosphere 2 – Then and Now|author=Staff|first=|date=May 2017|publisher=Institute for Modern and Contemporary Culture|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109135204/http://instituteformodern.co.uk/2017/proving-grounds-biosphere-2-then-and-now|archive-date=9 November 2017|dead-url=no|accessdate=9 November 2017}}</ref> I.E. served as an ecological systems consultant and managed the organizing of scientific and design workshops both at Biosphere 2 and a series of International Workshops on Closed Ecological Systems and Biospherics held at the Royal Society in 1987, at the Institute of Biosphysics (Bios 3) in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia in 1989, at Biosphere 2 in 1992 and at the Linnean Society of London in 1996.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1997|title=Special Issue on Fourth International Symposium on Closed Ecological Systems, Biospherics and Life Support|url=|journal=Life Support Biosphere Science|volume=4 |issue=3–4 |pages=87–181|via=|pmid=11542293}}</ref> An [[Earth system science]] research facility or [[closed ecological system]] in [[Oracle, Arizona]], its inventor was Institute of Ecotechnics director [[John P. Allen]], and bankrolled by Texas financier, [[Ed Bass|Ed Bass, who also served as an I.E. for many years]].<ref name="Motherboard 1">{{cite web | author = Oberhaus | first = Daniel | title = A 21st Century 'Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth' | publisher = [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] | date = 10 June 2017 | url = https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/wjqnxy/the-decades-long-quest-to-recreate-earth-in-miniature | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109153044/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/wjqnxy/the-decades-long-quest-to-recreate-earth-in-miniature | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref> At the time, the Biosphere 2 project was the subject of much media attention, and there were allegations that this was not science but a stunt, and that the project had been a failure. Some of the controversy may have stemmed from the radical goals of the project - to develop methods of harmonizing its technosphere and living systems including a non-polluting, non-toxic farming, a challenge to business as usual which is damaging the Earth's biosphere.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pushing our Limits: Insights from Biosphere 2|last=Nelson|first=Mark|publisher=University of Arizona Press|year=2018|isbn=0816537321|location=Tucson AZ|pages=}}</ref> Also it fell into the contentious divide between analytic (reductionist) and integrative (holistic) science though the project employed both to create the world's first mini biosphere.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Allen|first=John|last2=et. al.|date=2003|title=The legacy of Biosphere 2 for the study of biospherics and closed ecological systems|url=|journal=Advances in Space Research|volume=31 |issue=7|pages=1629–1640|via=}}</ref> These allegations have been strenuously denied and refuted by some of those involved, including ecologist and author [[Mark Nelson (scientist)|Mark Nelson]], the chairman of the Institute of Ecotechnics and a Biosphere 2 crew member from 1991–1993, and Bill Dempster, the Biosphere 2 Director of Systems Engineering until 1994.<ref name="Motherboard 2">{{cite web | author = Dempster | first = Bill | title = "Statements about 'failure' and things 'going wrong' inevitably follow based on the incorrect statement of purpose." | publisher = [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] | date = 24 June 2017 | url = https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/gypak9/biosphere-2-was-science-not-a-stunt | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109134624/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/gypak9/biosphere-2-was-science-not-a-stunt | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref><ref name="Motherboard 3">{{cite web | author = Nelson | first = Mark | title = Setting the Record Straight About the Biosphere 2 | publisher = [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] | date = 24 June 2017 | url = https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/mbjz43/setting-the-record-straight-about-the-biosphere-2 | accessdate = 9 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171109134810/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/mbjz43/setting-the-record-straight-about-the-biosphere-2 | archive-date = 9 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref> A wealth of scientific results have been published from the early closure experiments, 1991-1994, including a compendium of research papers published in the journal Ecological Engineering in reprinted as an Elsevier book, "Biosphere 2 Research Past and Present edited by H.T. Odum and Bruno Marino.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Biosphere 2: Research Past and Present (Ecological Engineering Special Issue, Volume 13, Numbers 1-4)|last=Odum|first=H.T.|publisher=Elsevier Science|year=1999|isbn=978-0080432083|location=New York, NY|pages=}}</ref>
== Other consultancies and collaborations == The Institute works in collaboration with the Biospherics Academy's ''Academia Biospherica'' program, which organizes workshops, lectures and events in the fields of [[restoration ecology]], [[Interculturalism|intercultural studies]] and [[the arts]].<ref name="AcademiaBiospherica">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = Academia Biospherica Program: About | publisher = Biospherics Academy | date = | url = https://abprogram.org/acerca-de/ | accessdate = 10 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171110115704/https://abprogram.org/acerca-de/ | archive-date = 10 November 2017 | dead-url = no }}</ref>
Past projects include consulting on the Hotel Vajra in Kathmandu, Nepal, working with a community of Tibetan refugees to create a travelers' hotel where East and West can meet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hotelvajra.com|title=Hotel Vajra|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 January 2018}}</ref> In Ft. Worth, I.E. was involved in the development of a jazz club, cultural and arts complex, the [[Caravan of Dreams]], to help revive the city center. I.E. was involved in the first Wastewater Garden (constructed wetlands) project in Algeria<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Wastewater Gardener: Preserving the Planet One Flush at a Time|last=Nelson|first=Mark|publisher=Synergetic Press|year=2014|isbn=0907791514|location=Santa Fe NM|pages=}}</ref> and in other applications of the ecotechnic technology, including a proposed project to protect the Marsh Arabs and their environment from sewage pollution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.meridelrubenstein.com/eden-in-iraq/|title=Eden in Iraq: the Wastewater Project|last=Rubinstein|first=Meridel|date=|website=Eden in Iraq, Meridel Rubinstein|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Mark|date=July 2014|title=Adam and Eve's Sewage Problem|url=https://www.thesolutionsjournal.com/article/adam-and-eves-sewage-problem/|journal=The Solutions Journal|volume=5 |issue=4|pages=17–22|via=}}</ref>

The '''Kartvelian studies''' ({{lang-ka|ქართველოლოგია}}) also referred as '''Kartvelology''' or '''Georgian studies''' is a field of humanities covering Kartvelian (Georgian) [[History of Georgia (country)|history]], [[Kartvelian languages|languages]], [[Religion and religious freedom in Georgia|religion]] and/or [[Culture of Georgia (country)|culture]].
In a narrower sense, the term usually refers to the research activities conducted on these problems outside Georgia.

{{Infobox institute |name= Kavli Institute for Cosmology, Cambridge |image= Kavli_Building_(2009)_South_East_elevations_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1409972.jpg |established=2006 |faculty=[[University of Cambridge#Schools.2C faculties and departments|School of Physical Sciences]], University of Cambridge |head_label= Director |head= Roberto Maiolino |staff= 48<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kicc.cam.ac.uk/directory| title=Kavli Institute: People| accessdate=28 July 2012| publisher=Kavli Institute for Cosmology, Cambridge}}</ref> |location= [[Cambridge]], [[Cambridgeshire]], [[United Kingdom]] |address= Madingley Road |website= [http://www.kicc.cam.ac.uk/ www.kicc.cam.ac.uk] }}
'''The Kavli Institute for Cosmology''', [[Cambridge]] ('''KICC''') is a research establishment set up through collaboration of the [[University of Cambridge]] and the [[Kavli Foundation (United States)|Kavli Foundation]]. It is operated by two of the University's astronomy groups: the [[Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge|Institute of Astronomy]] (IoA) and the [[Cavendish Astrophysics Group]].
==Background== In August 2006 an agreement was reached between the University of Cambridge and the Kavli Foundation for the establishment of an Institute for [[cosmology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kavlifoundation.org/kavli-news/university-cambridge-and-kavli-foundation-create-pioneering-new-research-center-examine-v| title=The University of Cambridge and The Kavli Foundation Create a Pioneering New Research Center to Examine the Very Beginnings of the Universe| accessdate=28 July 2012| date=1 November 2006| work=Kavli News |publisher=The Kavli Foundation}}</ref> The Kavli Foundation will support several 5-year senior research fellowships in perpetuity, and the University committed to provide a building to house the Institute. Operation began in October 2008 with the appointment of the first Kavli Institute Fellows. The building was completed in July 2009, and was officially opened 18 November 2009 by [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]] as [[List of Chancellors of the University of Cambridge|Chancellor of the University]] in a ceremony with [[Fred Kavli]].
The director of the Institute is Roberto Maiolino; the deputy director is Anthony Challinor. The first director was [[George Efstathiou]] of the IoA.
==Projects== KICC researchers are involved in the following projects:
* [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array]] * [[Dark Energy Survey]] * [[Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument]] * [[Extremely Large Telescope]] * [[Illustris project]] * [[James Webb Space Telescope]] * KLEVER (Kmos LEnsed Velocity and Emission line Review) * [[Large Synoptic Survey Telescope]] * MaNGA sky survey * MOONS galaxy survey * Planck cosmological survey * [[Square Kilometre Array]] * [[Simons Observatory]]
==Kavli Building==
The Kavli Building is located adjacent to the Hoyle Building, the main building of the IoA. The two are connected via a raised walkway. The building was designed to encourage the occupants to interact with one another as well as with the occupants of the Hoyle building. It is intended to be similar in architectural style to the Hoyle Building, but to be sufficiently distinctive so as to retain an independent identity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amarch.co.uk/architecture/kavli-institute-cosmology-cambridge| title=Kavli Institute: Architecture| accessdate=28 July 2012| date=2008|publisher=Kavli Institute for Cosmology, Cambridge}}</ref> The architects were Annand and Mustoe. The design includes use of ground source heat pumps and a heat exchanger serving under-floor heating to meet [[Cambridge City Council|City Council]] requirements that at least 10% of the building's energy is generated on-site.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{For|fossilized feces in geological contexts|Coprolite}}
'''Paleofeces''' (UK: Palaeofaeces) are ancient [[human feces]], often found as part of [[archaeology|archaeological]] excavations or surveys. The term [[coprolite]] is often used interchangeably. Intact feces of ancient people may be found in caves in arid climates and in other locations with suitable preservation conditions. They are studied to determine the [[diet (nutrition)|diet]] and [[health]] of the people who produced them through the analysis of seeds, small bones, and parasite eggs found inside. The feces can contain information about the person excreting the material as well as information about the material itself. They can also be chemically analyzed for more in-depth information on the individual who excreted them, using [[lipid]] analysis and ancient [[DNA]] analysis. The success rate of usable DNA extraction is relatively high in paleofeces, making it more reliable than skeletal DNA retrieval.<ref>A Molecular Analysis of Dietary Diversity for Three Archaic Native Americans. Hendrik N. Poinar et al. PNAS 10 April 2001: 98 (8) 4317-4322. [DOI 10.1073/pnas.061014798]</ref>
The reason this analysis is possible at all is due to the digestive system not being entirely efficient, in the sense that not everything that passes through the digestive system is destroyed. Not all of the surviving material is recognizable, but some of it is. This material is generally the best indicator archaeologists can use to determine ancient diets, as no other part of the archaeological record is as direct an indicator.<ref>Feder, Kenneth L., Linking to the Past: A Brief Introduction to Archaeology. New York: Oxford University Press, 2008. Print.</ref>
The process that preserves the feces in a way such that they can be analyzed later is called the [[Maillard reaction]]. This reaction creates a casing of sugar that preserves the feces from the elements. To extract and analyze the information contained within, researchers generally have to freeze the feces and grind it up into powder for analysis.<ref>Divining Diet and Disease From DNA. Erik Stokstad. Science 28 July 2000: 289 (5479), 530-531. [DOI:10.1126/science.289.5479.530]</ref>
==History of research==
Analysis of archaeological feces has a relatively short history compared to many other archaeological materials. The founder of the discipline is Dr. Eric O. Callen, who pioneered the subject in the late 1950s to mid-1960s.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Archaeological coprolite science: The legacy of Eric O. Callen (1912–1970)|doi=10.1016/j.palaeo.2005.11.032|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018206001027|year=2013|last1=Bryant|first1= V.|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|volume=237|issue=1|pages=51–66}} </ref> His early papers used coprolite analysis to investigate early Mexican diets, published in The Prehistory of the Tehuacan Valley: Environment, and Subsistence. Despite his work showing promise, archaeological coprolite studies remained a niche topic, with few other researchers becoming involved. After Callen's sudden death in 1970, his work was continued by [http://anthropology.tamu.edu/html/profile--vaughnbryant.html Vaughn Bryant] at [[Texas A&M University]], Department of Anthropology. Coprolite analysis gradually became a topic of serious study. Today coprolite analysis in archaeology has increased exponentially, and they have provided important evidence concerning the evolution of human health and diet, in the Americas and other parts of the world.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Biomolecular and micromorphological analysis of suspected faecal deposits at Neolithic Çatalhöyük, Turkey|doi=10.1016/j.jas.2011.03.031|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305440311001166|year=2011|last1=Shillito|first1= L-M.|journal=Journal of Archaeological Science|volume=38|issue=8|pages=1869–1877|display-authors=etal}}</ref> One of the most famous examples is the coprolite from [[Paisley Caves]], Oregon, which has provided some of the earliest evidence for the human occupation of North America.<ref>http://www.sciencemag.org/content/320/5877/786.abstract</ref>
==Methods of analysis==
A wide variety of methods can be used to analyse ancient feces, ranging from microscopic to molecular. At a basic level the analysis of size and morphology can provide some information on whether they are likely to be human or from another animal. Analyzed contents can include those visible to the naked eye, such as seeds and other plant remains—to the microscopic, including pollen and phytoliths. Parasites in coprolites can give information on the living conditions and health of ancient populations.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1879981713000405 | doi=10.1016/j.ijpp.2013.04.003 | volume=3 | title=Human intestinal parasites from a latrine in the 12th century Frankish castle of Saranda Kolones in Cyprus | journal=International Journal of Paleopathology | pages=218–223}}</ref> At the molecular level, ancient [[DNA]] analysis can be used both to identify the species and to provide dietary information. A method using [[lipid]] analysis can also be used for species identification, based on the range of fecal [[sterols]] and [[bile acids]].<ref>http://antiquity.ac.uk/ant/073/Ant0730086.htm</ref> These molecules vary between species according to gut biochemistry, and so can distinguish between humans and other animals.
An example of researchers using paleofeces for the gathering of information using DNA analysis occurred at Hinds Cave in Texas by Hendrik Poinar and his team. The fecal samples obtained were over 2,000 years old. From the samples, Poinar was able to gather DNA samples using the analysis methods recounted above. From his research Poinar found that the feces belonged to three Native Americans, based on mtDNA similarities to present day Native Americans. Poinar also found DNA evidence of the food they ate. There were samples of buckthorn, acorns, ocotillo, nightshade and wild tobacco. No visible remnants of these plants were visible in the fecal matter. Along with plant material, there were also DNA sequences of animal species such as bighorn sheep and pronghorn antelope, both of which lack any evidence elsewhere in Hinds Cave, indicating that they were killed and consumed elsewhere.
This analysis of the diet was very helpful. Previously it was assumed that this population of Native Americans survived with berries being their main source of nutrients. From the paleofeces, it was determined that these assumptions were incorrect and in the approximately 2 days of food that are represented in a fecal sample, 2-4 animal species and 4-8 plant species were represented. The nutritional diversity of this archaic human population was rather extraordinary.<ref>A Molecular Analysis of Dietary Diversity for Three Archaic Native Americans. Hendrik N. Poinar et al. PNAS 10 April 2001: 98 (8) 4317-4322. [DOI 10.1073/pnas.061014798]</ref>
An example of the use of lipid analysis for identification of species is at the Neolithic site of [[Catalhoyuk]] in Turkey. Large midden deposits at the site are frequently found to contain fecal material <ref>http://www.world-archaeology.com/features/turkey-neolithic-life-at-catalhoyuk.htm</ref> either as distinct coprolites or compressed 'cess pit' deposits. This was initially thought to be from dog on the basis of digested bone, however an analysis of the lipid profiles showed that many of the coprolites were actually from humans.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305440311001166 | doi=10.1016/j.jas.2011.03.031 | volume=38 | title=Biomolecular and micromorphological analysis of suspected faecal deposits at Neolithic Çatalhöyük, Turkey | journal=Journal of Archaeological Science | pages=1869–1877}}</ref>
The analysis of parasites from fecal material within cesspits has provided evidence for health and migration in past populations. For example, the identification of fish tapeworm eggs in Acre in the Crusader period indicate that this parasite was transported from northern Europe. The parasite was rarely seen in the Levant area during this time but was common in Northern Europe. It is suggested that it was brought to the region by the incoming Europeans.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1879981711000337 | doi=10.1016/j.ijpp.2011.10.005 | volume=1 | title=Human intestinal parasites in crusader Acre: Evidence for migration with disease in the medieval period | journal=International Journal of Paleopathology | pages=132–137}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Coprolite]]
==References== <references />

{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}} '''Parasitic computing''' is programming technique where a program in normal authorized interactions with another program manages to get the other program to perform computations of a complex nature. It is, in a sense, a security exploit in that the program implementing the parasitic computing has no authority to consume resources made available to the other program.
It was first proposed by Albert-Laszlo Barabasi, Vincent W. Freeh, Hawoong Jeong & Jay B. Brockman from University of Notre Dame, Indiana, USA, in 2001.<ref>[http://www3.nd.edu/~parasite/ Parasitic Computing]</ref> The example given by the original paper was two computers communicating over the [[Internet]], under disguise of a standard communications session. The first computer is attempting to solve a large and extremely difficult [[3-SAT]] problem; it has decomposed the original 3-SAT problem in a considerable number of smaller problems. Each of these smaller problems is then encoded as a relation between a [[checksum]] and a [[Packet (information technology)|packet]] such that whether the checksum is accurate or not is also the answer to that smaller problem. The packet/checksum is then sent to another computer. This computer will, as part of receiving the packet and deciding whether it is valid and [[well-formed element|well-formed]], create a checksum of the packet and see whether it is identical to the provided checksum. If the checksum is invalid, it will then request a new packet from the original computer. The original computer now knows the answer to that smaller problem based on the second computer's response, and can transmit a fresh packet embodying a different sub-problem. Eventually, all the sub-problems will be answered and the final answer easily calculated.
The example is based on an exploit of the [[Transmission Control Protocol]] (TCP), used for internet connections, so in the end, the target computer(s) is unaware that it has performed computation for the benefit of the other computer, or even done anything besides have a normal [[TCP/IP]] session.
The proof-of-concept is obviously extremely inefficient as the amount of computation necessary to merely send the packets in the first place easily exceeds the computations leeched from the other program; and the 3-SAT problem would be solved much more quickly if just analyzed locally. In addition, in practice packets would probably have to be retransmitted occasionally when real checksum errors and network problems occur. However, parasitic computing on the level of checksums is a demonstration of the concept. The authors suggest that as one moves up the [[application stack]], there might come a point where there is a net computational gain to the parasite - perhaps one could break down interesting problems into queries of complex [[cryptographic protocol]]s using [[public key cryptography|public keys]]. If there was a net gain, one could in theory use a number of control nodes for which many hosts on the Internet form a [[distributed computing]] network completely unawares.
Students of the University of Applied Sciences, Bern, Switzerland, extended this concept into a programmable [[virtual machine]] in 2002.<ref>[http://www.szene.ch/parasit/index.html Diploma thesis on Parasitic Computing]</ref>
==See also== * [[Denial of service attack]]
==References== {{Reflist}} # [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hawoong_Jeong/publication/11818463_Parasitic_computing/links/02bfe50e76eb6633e2000000.pdf "Parasitic computing"], Barabasi et al., ''Nature'', '''412''': 894-897 (2001).
==External links==
